node_2: effective moral to be applied in life
edge: The director stated that the approach of vengeance in the film needs to be significantly tempered by anyone who would want to see vengeance as either an effective or useful moral to be applied in life.
The director said that there can only be a disappointment and lack of fulfillment for anyone who looks to revenge as providing a higher purpose for living or a life-defining purpose.

node_2: james fenimore cooper's literary works, particularly the last of the mohicans
edge: Critic Wai Chee Dimock compared The Revenant's themes with those addressed in the literary works of James Fenimore Cooper, particularly The Last of the Mohicans. Dimock argues that the film reinterprets the concept of 'half-breeds' from a derogatory idea that Cooper despised to an aesthetic way in which to see the world.
Critic Wai Chee Dimock compared both works' protagonists—Glass and Hawk-eye—as literary foils, with Glass living an inversion of the latter's biography and perspective.

node_2: recurrent theme from his previous works
edge: In the documentary A World Unseen, the director stated that for The Revenant's main themes, he revisits the issues and concerns of intense parental and filial relations, which are readily recognizable as a recurrent theme from his previous works.
